info.senderName: NWS Albuquerque (Northern and Central New Mexico)
info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued October 21 at 1:57PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque
info.description: ...STRONG WINDS, COLDER TEMPERATURES, RAIN SHOWERS, AND HIGHER TERRAIN SNOW IN STORE FOR THIS WEEKEND INTO EARLY NEXT WEEK... The first significant fall storm system will slide through New Mexico this weekend into early next week with big changes from the recent stretch of spectacular weather. West to southwest winds are increasing over the region today and will continue to strengthen through Saturday and Sunday. The strongest winds are likely over the high terrain and across much of eastern NM Sunday when gusts of 45 to 60 mph will be common. Strong crosswinds will make travel difficult for large and high profile vehicles. Secure outdoor holiday decorations to avoid objects becoming airborne or damaged. A powerful cold front will surge southeast through the region on Sunday night with much colder air and gusty northwest winds. Rain and high terrain snow showers are also expected to develop over parts of the area as well through Monday morning. The coverage of rain and snow may increase over a larger area of New Mexico by Monday and Monday night with potential for several inches of snow in the higher terrain and nearby highlands. Confidence remains low on the snowfall aspect of this storm however folks across the region should prepare for much colder temperatures and potential winter travel conditions through the high terrain. Stay tuned to the latest forecast, watches, and warnings for changes to the weather forecast.
